commit_message:
Prevent to create member with vip address of lb

Added check during creation of pool member, that address specified as address
for pool member not the same as vip of loadbalancer.
Also apiv2 tempest test added for this case.

Change-Id: I521850dbdbc22b615ec0331fe58fef5af582c924
Closes-Bug: #1596162
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lbaas refs/changes/17/337117/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Provide logs for each task start

This is meant to help with debugging CI runs.  Indicates quickly how
long each task took to run.

This change set also removes some now redundant messages in the tasks.
Lastly, it also updates some of the task names to be more clear as
they're now represented in the logs directly.

Change-Id: I6ca776f1651d4c9542da0561e4152c40f1e4553a

Add e1000-kmod package

This package includes patched version
of the e1000 driver, which resolves
"tx unit hang" issue.

commit_message:
Merge pacemaker_master/sync_db conditionals

By condensing the pacemaker_master and sync_db conditions we ensure
there won't be unrelevant (clustercheck) execs deployed on
non-bootstrap nodes.

Closes-Bug: 1598907
Change-Id: Iae6aa13682d63096265f4751b2f71019a49f6fa6
(cherry picked from commit 3b9544b265ff239225ef7a23986182019a14d34b)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/44/339444/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines:
exec { 'galera-ready' : command => '/usr/bin/clustercheck >/dev/null', timeout => 30, tries => 180, try_sleep => 10, environment => ['AVAILABLE_WHEN_READONLY=0'], require => Exec['create-root-sysconfig-clustercheck'], } # We add a clustercheck db user and we will switch /etc/sysconfig/clustercheck # to it in a later step. We do this only on one node as it will replicate on # the other members. We also make sure that the permissions are the minimum necessary password_hash => mysql_password(hiera('mysql_clustercheck_password')), # Create all the database schemas # This step is to create a sysconfig clustercheck file with the root user and empty password # on the first install only (because later on the clustercheck db user will be used) # We are using exec and not file in order to not have duplicate definition errors in puppet # when we later set the the file to contain the clustercheck data exec { 'create-root-sysconfig-clustercheck': command => "/bin/echo 'MYSQL_USERNAME=root
MYSQL_PASSWORD=''
MYSQL_HOST=localhost
' > /etc/sysconfig/clustercheck", unless => '/bin/test -e /etc/sysconfig/clustercheck && grep -q clustercheck /etc/sysconfig/clustercheck', } xinetd::service { 'galera-monitor' : port => '9200', server => '/usr/bin/clustercheck', per_source => 'UNLIMITED', log_on_success => '', log_on_failure => 'HOST', flags => 'REUSE', service_type => 'UNLISTED', user => 'root', group => 'root', require => Exec['create-root-sysconfig-clustercheck'], } $mysql_clustercheck_password = hiera('mysql_clustercheck_password') $mysql_root_password = hiera('mysql::server::root_password')

commit_message:
Add client caching for Mistral actions

This simply returns an existing client object if one already exists from
a prior request.

Change-Id: I0948772c705efff62436b567181f2baab64f6be1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common refs/changes/63/329163/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Repurpose KeystoneWorkers add keystone::wsgi::apache::threads
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-01 11:49:16.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/2dcb59a345585d73275c0f86d88853b487dd314e', 'message': 'Add keystone::wsgi::apache params for keystone under wsgi

Now that keystone is run with wsgi apache the KeystoneWorkers param
has no efffect [1]. We adds the KeystoneWsgiApacheWorkers and
KeystoneWsgiApacheThreads parameters instead. These are especially
useful for deployments with multicore nodes where performance is
greatly improved by tuning these - see the bug for info.

commit_message:
Repurpose KeystoneWorkers add keystone::wsgi::apache::threads

Now that keystone is run with wsgi apache the KeystoneWorkers
param has no efffect [1]. This repurposes KeystoneWorkers to
now set wsgi::apache::workers and adds the
keystone::wsgi::apache::threads hardcoding to 1 in controller
hieradata.

In master at https://review.openstack.org/#/c/336472/

[1] https://github.com/openstack/puppet-keystone/blob/51c68fb127c28b9748b352871783c3ec6ef5c83b/manifests/init.pp#L396

Closes-Bug: 1598092
Change-Id: Ife898e83efc523e5258dc32a578813acf4fee3fa
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/20/336520/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: KeystoneWsgiApacheWorkers: type: number description: Set the number of workers for keystone::wsgi::apache (otherwise puppet-keystone defaults) default: 1 #module default KeystoneWsgiApacheThreads: default: 1 type: number description: Set the number of threads for keystone::wsgi::apache (otherwise puppet-keystone defaults) keystone_wsgi_workers: {get_param: KeystoneWsgiApacheWorkers} keystone_wsgi_threads: {get_param: KeystoneWsgiApacheThreads} keystone::wsgi::apache::workers: {get_input: keystone_wsgi_workers} keystone::wsgi::apache::threads: {get_input: keystone_wsgi_threads}

subject: devref for public API docstring
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-11 21:37:48.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lib/commit/5efb18b43638666f5daeb16b4455d08362b00e23', 'message': "devref for public API pydoc

This patch proposes that we require public APIs to be fully
documented with pydoc in the source. This has the following
implications:
- Rehomed code that's missing such pydocs requires a bug
to track that the pydocs get updated in lib with a follow-on
patch. The bug # should be included in the rehome patch(es).
- New public function in lib is fully documented.

If this patch lands; it also means that I'll create a bug and
go through all the undocumented public API in lib and update
it :)

commit_message:
devref for public API docstring

This patch updates our review guidelines with respect to
public API docstrings. While we want to encourage docstrings,
we don't want hard enforcement that may result in a raised
entry barrier for lib contributors.

I'll investigate the ability to implement a warn-only hacking check
for docstrings. This would allow us to identify and cleanup
pydoc "debt" if we desired.

Change-Id: I73734e4acc34ed7716e3daceb664cebbf045c8ff
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lib refs/changes/80/340580/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - Does the code have pydoc including param's and returns (see pydoc section below)? If not, open a neutron defect and tag it with ``lib``. This defect should be used for a follow-on patch that adds pydoc to the rehomed public API it's bug ID should be included in the commit message for rehomed code. * All public APIs should have pydoc source including: - An overview of the functionality implemented. - Param doc for each argument. - Return value documentation. For example:: def say_hi_to(name): """Prints a simple hi message to the said name. If I was interesting, a better description of what I do would go here. :param name: The name to address when saying hi. :return: None """ print("Hi there %s" % name)

commit_message:
Deprecate N523 check that forbids oslo.* imports

Oslo libraries don't ship oslo.* import namespace for a while, so there
is no real need to check against its usage. Since the module is public,
we need to follow deprecation process.

Note that only direct usage of the check is supported. Factory does not
register it anymore.

Change-Id: I48dc1555fd2c77708fd44f3eed4617f636c346de

commit_message:
Restart glance-glare service after installing murano-glance plugin

After installing package murano-glance-artifacts-plugin Glare service
must be restarted, otherwise Murano will not work correctly with Glare.

Change-Id: Ib76676bc48f1e3f8415801112a2cf3f0e6667b25
Closes-bug: #1597368

commit_message:
Do not install murano-glance-artifacts-plugin from Glance task

This package is required only by Murano and when Glare for Murano
is enabled. So, we don't need it for Glance at all.

Change-Id: I7dbc42ed11602f06d7424de7a896fb01dd99ffd4
Closes-bug: #1590714
(cherry picked from commit dc1a3f7f5300a7e0c4ca90476ebfd9fe8646d883)

commit_message:
Add class 2 driver support

There has been an ongoing conflict of concerns with drivers being
proposed to be added to Cinder. Some vendors see this as a marketing
requirement to be able to show their customers they are an "official"
driver, but they don't have the desire, resources, or ability to fully
commit to providing their driver as open source code and be involved in
the community.

These types of scenarios do not benefit Cinder whatsoever. But at the
same time, they are also a continual source of distraction each release
and have led to some vendors trying different ways to work around
getting code into Cinder while keeping the core of their driver code
closed source, or at least separate and not easily visible to the Cinder
team to review and validate there are no issues.

This proposes a new classification of driver as a compromise for these
drivers that will hopefully minimize the impact on the Cinder community
while giving these vendors some way to show they have working drivers,
even if they can't fully be included in Cinder.

Change-Id: I25ba23ecb6671edb90ba62573e5f61f8e540d006
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder-specs refs/changes/80/341780/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =================================== Allow out of tree drivers in Cinder =================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/class-2-drivers There has been a strong desire from some vendors to have "official" Cinder drivers, but a resistence to have them fully open source and included in the Cinder source tree. This spec introduces a second class of Cinder volume drivers to help address this need, while also attempting to ease the burden on the Cinder community from doing code reviews and updates for drivers from companies that are not fully committed to the open tenets of OpenStack. Problem description =================== Nearly every release cycle includes some vendor proposing to add a trivial shim driver with no real code that just calls out to an external, often closed source, library that the end user must install first. There are also a lot of questions asked of the community from vendors that have developed their own drivers internally, and they do not want to make them open source, but they would like Cinder to publish them as offical drivers. Neither of these benefit Cinder as a whole. Nor do they allow us to ensure that end users consuming these drivers will have a reasonable expectation that there will not be issues. We are not able to review the code for issues, and they do not allow us to inspect the code as we make changes to the core Cinder code to make sure we don't break a driver. This attempts to address these issues by creating a separate class of driver that has a different level of expectations and restrictions. Use Cases ========= A customer is interested in deploying an OpenStack cloud and using Cinder. They have storage from a company that claims they work with Cinder, but they do not have a driver in the Cinder source code. The customer wants some assurances that the driver is going to work when they deploy it. Proposed change =============== A new class of driver will be added to Cinder that does not need to be included in the Cinder source. These drivers may or may not be open source. These will be classified as "class 2" drivers. To be "approved" as this class 2 driver, the vendor must meet the following requirements: 1. The vendor must implement and maintain a working third party CI system for all drivers for as long as they want this driver listed as an offical class 2 driver. All of the existing third party CI requirements that apply to in-tree drivers would apply to external drivers. 2. Installation handling will be included in the new driver installation tool to be added to support this. A new command line tool will be added for handling class 2 driver installation. This will allow deployers to install class 2 drivers separately to their individual installations. The tool will need to run with elevated permissions to allow installation of Python packages. The basic syntax will be something like:: sudo cinder-driver install external-driver-name To have a driver approved and added as a class 2 driver, vendors will set up their CI systems and make sure they are stable. They will then submit a patch adding awareness of their driver to the cinder-driver command. The Cinder community will treat this as a light weight driver review, similar to how we treat new drivers now with the notable exception that we will not need to review the driver source code. The core team's responsibility will be to verify the third party CI has been reporting, contains all the logs and other test artifacts required, and that the update to cinder-driver is able to install the external driver. No additional functional validation or quality assertions will need to be done by the Cinder team. The main work to implement this concept in Cinder is the introduction of this cinder-driver command line tool. The tool itself will be fairly light weight. It will start up and validate it is running with root privileges. It will then use an internal lookup for the requested driver to find what to load and run to perform the driver installation. The vendor patch for adding the class 2 driver will add their information to this map and add source code to perform their vendor specific installation options. In most cases this could just be a wrapper to call "pip install -y external-driver-package". In other cases this could be a more complicated script to download the driver from its source and perform additional operations to get it installed. It would not be recommended, but in some cases it may also be possible to have this installation script just print out instructions of where to go for a full installation guide hosted by the vendor. Alternatives ------------ Some alternatives are: 1. Keep things as they are and have team distractions recurring each release 2. Move all drivers out of tree and leave deployment up to the vendors Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- It is a security concern to run an elevated command that downloads and installs packages online. This is an existing concern with "pip install" commands, but somewhat mitigated by the fact that users can browse and inspect the package on pypi first if they choose to do so. We may want to consider adding a warning to the cinder-driver install command for drivers that are not installed via pypi to have the deployer explicitly give the OK to download and install a package from a third party location. The assumption would be the deployer would have gone ahead of time and validated that package was OK before performing the local installation. As another alternative, we could only allow pip installs or printing out installation instructions. No other installation types would be allowed. Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- Once deployed, there will be no different impact on the end user. Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- Deployers will need to be aware of the additional installation step required for their chosen backend. Developer impact ---------------- There will not be an additional impact on developers. When making core Cinder changes that may affect drivers, in-tree drivers may be inspected to scope the impact the change will have. But part of the implication of being a class 2 driver and not closely tied in to Cinder is that changes can (and likely will) happen in Cinder that could break external drivers. It is the responsibility of these vendors to monitor changes and their CI status to know when they need to make updates to their drivers. If a CI fails for several days with no updates from the vendor, or if the CI has stopped reporting on the status of external drivers, the driver mapping will be removed from the cinder-driver command and no longer be considered a class 2 driver. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: sean-mcginnis Other contributors: Work Items ---------- Immediate work items would be to add the cinder-driver command line with the following options:: install <driver_name> Uses vendor provided script to perform installation of driver_name. list Prints out list of available external drivers. info <driver_name> Prints out any driver information the vendor would like to provide. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= None Documentation Impact ==================== Documentation will need to be added to the deployment guides with information on how to discover and install third party external drivers. A devref page will need to be added with instructions for vendors to follow on how to add their external driver. References ========== None

commit_message:
Set haproxy state to up when got 401 error

Haproxy state should be set to up, when got 401 code from client
side - Unauthorized - that means that backend is ready and up.

Change-Id: I65b6e6789ac376a2ba0c95f03f6963fed804ba2d
Closes-bug: #1597416
(cherry picked from commit 7e4afb7a6fe9a335ad0d7b66a6231da1c31599ef)

commit_message:
Remove unnecessary overrides of service variables

The heat service user, project, region, and password are the same
regardless of the heat service endpoints.

Use the existing heat namespaced variables instead of overriding and
providing a generic 'service_' variable for use with the service setup
tasks.

This also fixes a recursive loop issue seen when deploying the
integrated release with Ansible 2.1.

Partial-Bug: 1603703
Change-Id: I350def02e04cd6d8279dcccade607ca3543ef4fa
(cherry picked from commit 42c11cb825d06971db3c41f77de3c0f421614bd9)

commit_message:
Make an automated db sync conditional.

As per other OpenStack puppet modules enable the user to disable the
automated db sync, separate from the choice whether to enable or disable
the api service.

Change-Id: Id3c9d2e1e48d3c515dab73c8eac220cfe826a880
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-manila refs/changes/47/345147/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: it 'should contain db_sync exec' do is_expected.to_not contain_exec('manila-manage db_sync')

commit_message:
Add a spec for a work queue messaging pattern

Use Tooz jobboard to adopt the Work Queue
pattern as well.

Related blueprint at-least-once-guarantee

Change-Id: I5faf9513542f346f8b841aa7018f3c082b15e428
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobrelia@mirantis.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-specs refs/changes/42/256342/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ============================================= At least once delivery for work queue pattern ============================================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/oslo.messaging/+spec/at-least-once-guarantee OpenStack projects like Mistral have identified a work queue pattern as a use case to be supported in Oslo messaging. Historically, Oslo messaging rpc delivery model is an "at-most-once". In order to support a work queue pattern, it should as well provide an "at-least-once" one and expose new API, which has nothing to the existing API for rpc. Problem description =================== At most once delivery ensures the "ack" to be send before the processing (dispatching) of a message and guarantees there would be no duplicates [#]_. At most once delivery model allows messages to disappear, which is highly unlikely for the work queue pattern there each message is a task for workers. That means that existing API for dispatching rpc can not fit needs of a work queue. From the other side, existing API for rpc can not be changed to the "at-least-once" delivery model as that might render rpc workers to return duplicated replies or messages being processed twice, which is highly unlikely for rpc pattern. .. [#] Note that the guarantees are not strong. Duplicates are still possible. Proposed change =============== Given that said, the solution is to add new API for a work queue. There should be new method ``ensure()`` or ``distribute()``, which resembles the ``_dispatch_and_reply`` of the ``RPCDispatcher`` class. But new method should provide the "at-least-once" delivery model and may normally return nothing to the caller side. It may also return an error or event that says "did not receive the ACK in X msec after Y attempts" but even so it cannot guarantee that the corresponding request was not in fact committed by the server. It should also give no strong guarantees for messages delivery. Messages may be lost in distributed systems. As well as duplicated or delivered in an arbitrary order. Therefore, the new method must guarantee serializable [#]_ "at-least-once" delivery for messages to be distributed. Besides that, the Oslo messaging library should not handle duplicated or lost or delivered out of order messages to a work queue. That should be the app side responsibility instead. The only way to handle those properly is to handle at the app server level in an atomic way - meaning the app must have a safe way to distinguish duplicates for those requests that are not idempotent and nobody else. The application has to bite the bullet and implement request idempotence and atomicity properly on the server side. .. [#] In distributed systems world, serializable means that the history of all operations is equivalent to one that took place in some single atomic order but with unknown invocation and completion times - it places no bounds on time or order. Alternatives ------------ * Ensure stronger delivery claims, like sequential. * Provide duplicates handling on the Oslo.messaging side * Rework existing API for rpc to support a work queue with at-least-once delivery as well as rpc with at-most-once one. Impact on Existing APIs ----------------------- The API for rpc shall be either reworked to support a work queue pattern, if the alternatives accepted, or unchanged but extended to provide a separate API for a work queue by new method ``ensure()`` or ``distribute()``. Security impact --------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Configuration Impact -------------------- TODO(bogdando) which configuration we want for new API dispatch/ensure? For the alternative solutions, new configuration parameter ``ack_then_process`` should be added to rpc call related classess and API to make the "at-least-once" or "at-most-once" delivery modes configurable. Developer Impact ---------------- OpenStack components developers will have to care for handling dulicated or lost or delivered in an unexpected order messages to a work queue. While for the alternative solutions, the Oslo.messaging library developers would have to handle that. Testing Impact -------------- Either new or reworked API for rpc / work queue must be covered by unit tests. These shall provide test cases for lost, duplicated, out of order delivered messages to a work queue / rpc conversation. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: <looking-for-volunteers!> Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: mitaka-1 Work Items ---------- * Design new API for a work queue pattern * Write the ``WorkQueueDispatcher`` class with at least ``ensure()`` or ``distribute()`` method * Design test cases * Update work queue use cases documentaion for developers Documentation Impact ==================== API and related dev docs shall be updated Dependencies ============ None References ========== * https://review.openstack.org/229186 * http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-December/080907.html .. note:: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode

subject: Enable passive deletes on trunk deletion
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-20 23:46:21.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/tests/tempest/api/test_trunk.py', 'neutron/services/trunk/models.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/29cc91ef25b678a2944fa5a5726aa2b84b14dded', 'message': 'Enable passive deletes on trunk deletion

Add missing sqlalchemy cascade="all, delete-orphan" on the
trunk-subports relationship to disable child object loading
on a trunk delete operation, otherwise sqlalchemy would
attempt to update the children with a NULL key, and cause
an integrity violation.

Deleting a trunk with subports is allowed, and a test is
added to cover that.

Partially-implements: blueprint vlan-aware-vms

Change-Id: I143c436ce6d2d3a441c26a4b08730981f1ec2973
'}]
commit_message:
Enable passive deletes on trunk deletion

Add missing sqlalchemy cascade="all, delete-orphan" on the
trunk-subports relationship to disable child object loading
on a trunk delete operation, otherwise sqlalchemy would
attempt to update the children with a NULL key, and cause
an integrity violation.

Deleting a trunk with subports is allowed, and a test is
added to cover that.

Partially-implements: blueprint vlan-aware-vms

Change-Id: I143c436ce6d2d3a441c26a4b08730981f1ec2973
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/01/345101/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: sub_ports = sa.orm.relationship( 'SubPort', lazy='joined', uselist=True, cascade="all, delete-orphan")

commit_message:
Implements: blueprint vitrage-heat-datasource

Change-Id: I0513fae7323abcd443f4d846f50cc52c36a49c16
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/vitrage-specs refs/changes/92/345392/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =============================================== Heat Datasource Driver - get_all implementation =============================================== launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/vitrage/+spec/heat-datasource-get-all This blueprint describes the Heat driver for Vitrage Datasource, and its implementation for get_all Stacks and Stack Resources. Problem description =================== Heat stacks should be added to Vitrage Graph via Vitrage Datasources. This requires writing a Datasource driver for heat. The driver should support two modes: * get_all: query all Heat Stacks. * notifications: notify the datasource upon a change in a stack definition or state This blueprint refers to get_all implementation. Proposed change =============== Heat driver will be configured with: * Poll interval in seconds (default: 60 - test wish Alosha) Every poll-interval seconds, Heat Driver will call Heat list all stacks API. The stacks will be converted to Vitrage datasource events and passed to Vitrage Graph queue. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- Heat event will be sent to Vitrage Graph queue with the following properties: +------------------+----------------------------------------------------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ | Field | Description | Examples | +==================+==========================================================+=====================================================+ | stack_id | The stack UUID | e47e1be6-3598-46e6-bb63-0cc9a4e35ad7 | +------------------+----------------------------------------------------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ | name | The stack name | mystack | +------------------+----------------------------------------------------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ | description | The stack description | mydescription | +------------------+----------------------------------------------------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ | user_project_id | The ID of the tenant that owns the alarm | 5542b27142154f30b32dea6238aa81aa | +------------------+----------------------------------------------------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ | owner | The ID of the user that owns the alarm | 5555527142154f30b32dea6238aa81aa | +------------------+----------------------------------------------------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ | status | The stack status | in progress / failed | +------------------+----------------------------------------------------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ | status_reason | The stack status reason | Stack create started .... | +------------------+----------------------------------------------------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ REST API impact --------------- None Versioning impact ----------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Deployer impact --------------- Heat driver should be configured Developer impact ---------------- None Horizon impact -------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: dan-offek Work Items ---------- None Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= This blueprint requires unit tests and Tempest tests. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== Datasource main blueprint: https://github.com/openstack/vitrage-specs/blob/master/specs/mitaka/vitrage-datasource.rst

commit_message:
Fix duplicated config options in auditd.conf

The regular expressions for max_log_file and space_left
were not specific enough and the options were repeated in the
auditd.conf over multiple runs of the security role. This patch
makes those regular expressions more specific.

Closes-bug: 1604958

Change-Id: Ia7eddd6fb4bdd3c2a5cc1b25aa9a152b087801c9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-security refs/changes/52/345052/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: regexp: "^(#)?max_log_file(?!_action)" regexp: "^(#)?space_left(?!_action)"

commit_message:
Update ml2 delete_subnet to deallocate via ipam

Previosly during delete_subnet in ml2 plugin ip allocation were removed
directly from database. This way ipam driver was unaware of this
deallocation.

Updated workflow to skip removing ip allocations directly from database.
Now ips are deallocated during update_port workflow (L1008).

This resolves issue with dhcp ports left in allocated state on ipam
provides side. Now they are correctly deallocated via update_port.

But this patch has next limitation: currently SLAAC allocations can
not be delete via update_port workflow, so ipam driver is still unaware
of such deallocations.
This part of issue is expected to be fixed as separate patch.

Subnet_in_use check was reworked. Previously it assumed that
auto-allocated ip are already deleted by the time of this check, but
with new workflow auto allocated ips are deleted later (on update_port).
So now this check verifies if there are any user allocated ips instead
of checking all allocations.

Partial-Bug: #1564335
Change-Id: I08d66da8cb57ed88e11ec2b18c8345edfce37d37
(cherry picked from commit 3a2e41bf703d6721fcfe4d72f9ad5c0565fef42d)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/74/330374/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

If transaction isolation # level is set to READ COMMITTED allocations made # concurrently will be returned by this query and transaction # will be restarted. It works for REPEATABLE READ isolation # level too because this query is executed only once during # transaction, and if concurrent allocations are detected # transaction gets restarted. Executing this query second time # in transaction would result in not seeing allocations # committed by concurrent transactions. if not to_deallocate: if (not is_auto_addr_subnet and self._subnet_check_ip_allocations(context, id)): # allocation found and it was DHCP port # that appeared after autodelete ports were # removed - need to restart whole operation raise os_db_exception.RetryRequest( exc.SubnetInUse(subnet_id=id)) for a in to_deallocate: deallocated.add(a)

In that case the check is # unnecessary. This additional check not only would be wasteful # for this class of subnet, but is also error-prone since when # the isolation level is set to READ COMMITTED allocations made # concurrently will be returned by this query if not is_auto_addr_subnet: alloc = self._subnet_check_ip_allocations(context, id) if alloc: user_alloc = self._subnet_get_user_allocation( context, id) if user_alloc: LOG.info(_LI("Found port (%(port_id)s, %(ip)s) " "having IP allocation on subnet " "%(subnet)s, cannot delete"), {'ip': user_alloc.ip_address, 'port_id': user_alloc.port_id, 'subnet': id}) raise exc.SubnetInUse(subnet_id=id) else: # allocation found and it was DHCP port # that appeared after autodelete ports were # removed - need to restart whole operation raise os_db_exception.RetryRequest( exc.SubnetInUse(subnet_id=id)) # If allocated is None, then all the IPAllocation were # correctly deleted during the previous pass. if not allocated: for a in allocated:

commit_message:
Change rgw frontend interface

Change the rgw frontend interface (from storage_interface to
api_interface) to make it consistent with the one specified in the
haproxy configuration.

Closes-Bug: #1603885
Change-Id: I8537f05575382faeac3ab915feaaad4af9b29565
(cherry picked from commit 94410d23cdebf5243e1a19d12cfa35c009749a57)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/11/344411/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: rgw frontends = civetweb port={{ hostvars[inventory_hostname]['ansible_' + api_interface]['ipv4']['address'] }}:{{ rgw_port }}
deleted_lines: rgw frontends = civetweb port={{ hostvars[inventory_hostname]['ansible_' + storage_interface]['ipv4']['address'] }}:{{ rgw_port }}

commit_message:
Cleanup i18n marker functions to match Oslo docs

Define marker functions as per documentation.
http://docs.openstack.org/developer/oslo.i18n/usage.html.
The i18n marker functions can be imported directly and
need not be limited to one function per import. So,
this patch is to cleanup the i18n marker functions.

Change-Id: I6592a9fe64cba25abb5560349fa553d68a688565
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance_store refs/changes/99/342699/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: from glance_store import i18n_ = i18n.__LI = i18n._LI

commit_message:
Replace "LOG.exception(_" with "LOG.exception(_LE"

Follow http://docs.openstack.org/developer/oslo.i18n/guidelines.html:
If a common message is not being used, they should each betreated
separately with respect to choosing a marker function.So this patch
is to fix it.

Change-Id: I2cd1fc1c6519db3369480c8cdc0c5610f7b539e9
Closes-Bug: #1600788
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance_store refs/changes/29/340329/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: _LE = i18n._LE msg = _LE("Failed to delete orphaned chunk " LOG.exception(_LE("Error during chunked upload " msg = _LE('Unable to delete segment %(segment_name)s')
deleted_lines: msg = _("Failed to delete orphaned chunk " LOG.exception(_("Error during chunked upload " msg = _('Unable to delete segment %(segment_name)s')

commit_message:
Fix Gnocchi py35 gate

This change allows to run custom tox target on ubuntu xenial

The Gnocchi jobs run some py35 jobs that are currently running on
trusty. But because it lacks of python3.5 we move them to xenial.

This fixes this Gnocchi gate issue:
http://logs.openstack.org/06/341606/5/check/gate-gnocchi-tox-db-py35-mysql/efda919/

Change-Id: I682b92a6baea6222d4e717b695f44c6ce8ff543e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/15/344215/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Resolve pep8 import issues

* H301 one import per line
* H302 import only modules
* H306  imports not in alphabetical order

copy from horizon.

Change-Id: Ie3fb071fef7e8889ad273e1838967ef95c73630f

commit_message:
[contributor] reorganize reviewing documentation chapter

Also, migrated the review guidelines from
https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Documentation/ReviewGuidelines

Change-Id: I1d6d97b0826869834e4252cb2458f5bd03233c73
Implements: blueprint contributor-guide-reorg
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/34/338634/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: OpenStack documentation is treated like code. We follow the standard code review porcess.`Documentation Program Dashboard <http://is.gd/openstackdocsreview>`_. It is organized in groupings based on the audience for the documentation. To see current proposed changes, make sure you register and log into https://review.openstack.org. For more details on the review process, see `Code Review <http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html#code-review>`_.The OpenStack Documentation team is core for api-site, openstack-manuals,How to review a documentation patch ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Before you proceed with reviewing patches, make sure to read carefully the :doc:`Review Guidelines <docs-review-guidelines>` for documentation and `Code Review Guidelines <http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html#code-review>`_. Once done, follow the steps below to submit a patch review. #. Go to the `Documentation Program Dashboard <http://is.gd/openstackdocsreview>`_. #. Click a patch set. #. Click a file that was uploaded to view the changes side by side. #. If you see some inconsistencies or have questions to the patch owner, double click the line in question for a ``Comment`` field to appear. Click ``Save`` button once you write a draft of your comment. #. In the ``Jenkins check`` section, click the Jenkins ``checkbuild`` gate link (for the openstack-manuals, it is called ``gate-openstack-manuals-tox-doc-publish-checkbuild``) and review the built manuals to see how the change will look on the web page. For a new patch, it takes some time before Jenkins checks appear on the Gerrit page. You can also `build the patch locally`_ if necessary. #. Click ``Reply`` to vote and enter any comments about your review, then click ``Post``. .. note:: A patch with WorkInProgress (WIP) status needs additional work before it gets merged. Therefore, you may skip such a patch and review once it is ready. For more information, see `Work In Progress <http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/core.html#work-in-progress>`_. .. seealso:: `Peer Review <http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html#peer-review>`_ .. _`build the patch locally`: How to build an existing patch locally -------------------------------------- Before proceeding, make sure you have all the necessary :ref:`tools <setting_up_for_contribution>` installed and set up for contribution. To build a patch locally: #. In terminal, switch to a necessary directory. For example: .. code-block:: console $ cd openstack-manuals #. Run the below command to create a local branch with the patch in question: .. code-block:: console $ git review -d <nnnnnn> where the value of <nnnnnn> is a Gerrit commit number. For example, 226632 is the commit number of the patch https://review.openstack.org/#/c/226632. #. Build all the books that are affected by changes in the patch set: .. code-block:: console $ sudo tox -e checkbuild #. Find the build result in :file:`openstack-manuals/publish-docs/index.html`. #. Review the source and the output. You are also welcomed to edit and update the patch: #. Ensure that your edits adhere to the :ref:`Writing Style <stg_writing_style>` for OpenStack documentation and uses standard US English. #. Once the build and new output are good to commit, run: .. code-block:: console $ git commit -a --amend #. When the editor opens, update the commit message if necessary. But do not add information on what your specific patch set changes. A reviewer can use the Gerrit interface to see the difference between patches. #. Save the changes if any and exit the editor. If your editor is vi, use the :command:`:wq` command to save the file and exit vi. #. Send your patch to the existing review: .. code-block:: console $ git review #. Leave a comment in Gerrit explaining the reason for your patch set. .. TODO: make a seealso and add a links to the below pages once converted to .RST: - https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Documentation/HowTo#Building_Output_Locally - https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Documentation/HowTo#Using_Tox_to_check_builds the core status in. Core status is granted to **those who have not only done a lot of reviews, but who also have shown care and wisdom in those reviews**.the **guardian of the gate**, and it is up to the core team to ensure that* Every month (usually on the 1st), the documentation PTL draws the top 12 * http://russellbryant.net/openstack-stats/docs-reviewers-30.txt * http://russellbryant.net/openstack-stats/docs-reviewers-90.txt * http://stackalytics.com/?module=openstack-manuals&metric=commits * The PTL then consults the existing core team with a list of names to be removed from and added to the core list. Once an agreement is reached, the changes are made and advertised to the main documentation mailing list. * Existing core team members can nominate a new core member at any time,.. toctree:: :maxdepth: 1 docs-review-guidelines.rst
deleted_lines: `Documentation Program Dashboard`_. It is organized in groupings based on the audience for the documentation. To see current proposed changes, make sure you register and log into https://review.openstack.org. commit_message:
Change rgw frontend interface

Change the rgw frontend interface (from storage_interface to
api_interface) to make it consistent with the one specified in the
haproxy configuration.

Closes-Bug: #1603885
Change-Id: I8537f05575382faeac3ab915feaaad4af9b29565
(cherry picked from commit 94410d23cdebf5243e1a19d12cfa35c009749a57)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/10/344410/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: rgw frontends = civetweb port={{ hostvars[inventory_hostname]['ansible_' + api_interface]['ipv4']['address'] }}:{{ rgw_port }}
deleted_lines: rgw frontends = civetweb port={{ hostvars[inventory_hostname]['ansible_' + storage_interface]['ipv4']['address'] }}:{{ rgw_port }}

prefix (this is true for 16.04).

commit_message:
Mcollective should be daemonized

In Xenial we use upstream mcollective with native
systemd service unit. This unit requires mcollective
to daemonize itself when started (Type=forking), so
we need to fix this in cloud-init config.

Change-Id: I39b64cae329b6515e42ac4e92f03ef9e64ec0d31
blueprint: mos-xenial

commit_message:

commit_message:
Ensure the Heat Domain parameters before starting heat-engine pcmk service

Heat needs stack_user_domain_id or stack_user_domain_name config options set
in the heat.conf before starting. The domain itself doesn't need to exist
until a stack is actually created, but the value needs to be there. This patch
ensures that the heat domain parameters are configured before starting the
heat-engine service with Pacemaker at step3 and 4, and at step5,
Pacemaker will start the services and Puppet will create the domains.

Closes-Bug: #1599232

Co-Authored-by: Gael Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-by: Emilien Macchi <emilien@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I9c6ad61208fecde61ee60163dd33b86a709c3802

commit_message:
Check lbaas version if call is v2 specific

lbaas/loadbalancers and lbaas/listeners are not supported in v1 lbaas
extension [1]

1. http://developer.openstack.org/api-ref-networking-v2-ext.html#lbaas-v1.0

Change-Id: I09dd0b5d98794ee773e010382f59fedb04123ff7
Closes-Bug: #1599482

commit_message:
Deprecate [ilo]/clean_priority_erase_devices config

The [ilo]/clean_priority_erase_devices configuration option is
duplicated by [deploy]/erase_devices_priority, this patch is marking the
ilo configuration as deprecated.

The ironic.conf.sample was also updated to reflect the changes.

Closes-Bug: #1515871
Change-Id: I2bf18e35d97160d31a51c8447745bfd60c099af2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/14/342114/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- deprecations: - The [ilo]/clean_priority_erase_devices config is deprecated and will be removed in the Ocata cycle. Please use the [deploy]/erase_devices_priority config instead.

commit_message:
Use consistent env variable naming

Old env variables are still supported but the default ones should
consistently use OS_ as prefix.

commit_message:
Remove contrib/devstack/docker code in kuryr

Since we seperate kuryr into kuryr-lib/kuryr-libnetwork.
We do not need this anymore in kuryr.

Partially Implements blueprint code-refactoring

Change-Id: I8ccdf690d1f5a3aaddeb2774cea1ded336a77070

commit_message:
Enforce ES2015 syntax

The whole project is going to use ES2015, so it's important to
enforce usage of the new syntax to the project code homogeneous.
This commit enforces usage of arrow functions where possible,
let/const instead of var and rest/spread operator instead of
arguments and call/apply.

Change-Id: I2fd33400d7d4a3ed23363ceaaf0c2d2f1bd55c47
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/js-openstack-lib refs/changes/28/342228/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: rules: # disallow unnecessary .call() and .apply() # http://eslint.org/docs/rules/no-useless-call no-useless-call: 2 # require let or const instead of var # http://eslint.org/docs/rules/no-var no-var: 2 # suggest using arrow functions as callbacks # http://eslint.org/docs/rules/prefer-arrow-callback prefer-arrow-callback: 2 # suggest using the spread operator instead of .apply(). # http://eslint.org/docs/rules/prefer-spread prefer-spread: 2 # suggest using the rest parameters instead of arguments # http://eslint.org/docs/rules/prefer-rest-params prefer-rest-params: 2

commit_message:
Remove datasource manager and related tests

Dse2 doesn't need datasource manager to control datasource driver.
This patch is a checker that makes sure dse2 codes don't import and
use datasource manager.

Don't merge this patch while deepsix is supported

Change-Id: Ie384042f7bdb6c7d07e75f3b1f33ca5dda49e99a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/congress refs/changes/86/339386/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. from __future__ import print_function from __future__ import division from __future__ import absolute_import from oslo_config import cfg cfg.CONF.distributed_architecture = True from congress import exception from congress.managers import datasource as datasource_manager from congress.tests import base from congress.tests import fake_datasource from congress.tests import helper from congress.policy_engines.agnostic import Dse2Runtime class TestDataSourceManager(base.SqlTestCase): def setUp(self): super(TestDataSourceManager, self).setUp() cfg.CONF.set_override( 'drivers', ['congress.tests.fake_datasource.FakeDataSource']) self.datasource_mgr = datasource_manager.DataSourceManager self.datasource_mgr.validate_configured_drivers() node = helper.make_dsenode_new_partition('testnode') self.dseNode = node engine = Dse2Runtime('engine') node.register_service(engine) self.datasource_mgr.set_dseNode(node) def _get_datasource_request(self): return {'id': 'asdf', 'name': 'aaron', 'driver': '', 'description': 'hello world!', 'enabled': True, 'type': None, 'config': {}} def test_make_datasource_dict(self): req = self._get_datasource_request() result = self.datasource_mgr.make_datasource_dict(req) self.assertEqual(req, result) def test_validate_create_datasource_invalid_driver(self): req = self._get_datasource_request() self.assertRaises(exception.InvalidDriver, self.datasource_mgr.validate_create_datasource, req) def test_validate_create_datasource_invalid_config_invalid_options(self): req = self._get_datasource_request() req['driver'] = 'invalid_datasource' self.assertRaises(exception.InvalidDriver, self.datasource_mgr.validate_create_datasource, req) def test_validate_create_datasource_missing_config_options(self): req = self._get_datasource_request() req['driver'] = 'fake_datasource' # This is still missing some required options req['config'] = {'auth_url': '1234'} self.assertRaises(exception.MissingRequiredConfigOptions, self.datasource_mgr.validate_create_datasource, req) def test_add_datasource(self): req = self._get_datasource_request() req['driver'] = 'fake_datasource' req['config'] = {'auth_url': 'foo', 'username': 'armax', 'password': 'password', 'tenant_name': 'armax'} # let driver generate this for us. del req['id'] result = self.datasource_mgr.add_datasource(req) for key, value in req.items(): self.assertEqual(value, result[key]) # TODO(thinrichs): test that ensure the DB, the policy engine, # and the datasource manager are all in sync def test_get_datasouce(self): req = self._get_datasource_request() req['driver'] = 'fake_datasource' req['config'] = {'auth_url': 'foo', 'username': 'armax', 'password': 'password', 'tenant_name': 'armax'} # let driver generate this for us. del req['id'] result = self.datasource_mgr.add_datasource(req) result = self.datasource_mgr.get_datasource(result['id']) for key, value in req.items(): self.assertEqual(value, result[key]) def test_get_datasources(self): req = self._get_datasource_request() req['driver'] = 'fake_datasource' req['name'] = 'datasource1' req['config'] = {'auth_url': 'foo', 'username': 'armax', 'password': 'password', 'tenant_name': 'armax'} # let driver generate this for us. del req['id'] self.datasource_mgr.add_datasource(req) req['name'] = 'datasource2' self.datasource_mgr.add_datasource(req) result = self.datasource_mgr.get_datasources() req['name'] = 'datasource1' for key, value in req.items(): self.assertEqual(value, result[0][key]) req['name'] = 'datasource2' for key, value in req.items(): self.assertEqual(value, result[1][key]) def test_get_datasources_hide_secret(self): req = self._get_datasource_request() req['driver'] = 'fake_datasource' req['name'] = 'datasource1' req['config'] = {'auth_url': 'foo', 'username': 'armax', 'password': 'password', 'tenant_name': 'armax'} # let driver generate this for us. del req['id'] self.datasource_mgr.add_datasource(req) req['name'] = 'datasource2' self.datasource_mgr.add_datasource(req) # Value will be set as <hidden> req['config']['password'] = "<hidden>" result = self.datasource_mgr.get_datasources(filter_secret=True) req['name'] = 'datasource1' for key, value in req.items(): self.assertEqual(value, result[0][key]) req['name'] = 'datasource2' for key, value in req.items(): self.assertEqual(value, result[1][key]) def test_create_datasource_duplicate_name(self): req = self._get_datasource_request() req['driver'] = 'fake_datasource' req['name'] = 'datasource1' req['config'] = {'auth_url': 'foo', 'username': 'armax', 'password': 'password', 'tenant_name': 'armax'} # let driver generate this for us. del req['id'] self.datasource_mgr.add_datasource(req) self.assertRaises(exception.DatasourceNameInUse, self.datasource_mgr.add_datasource, req) # TODO(dse2): need to implement dseNode.unregister_service to enable # delete_datasource # # def test_delete_datasource(self): # req = self._get_datasource_request() # req['driver'] = 'fake_datasource' # req['config'] = {'auth_url': 'foo', # 'username': 'armax', # 'password': 'password', # 'tenant_name': 'armax'} # # let driver generate this for us. # del req['id'] # result = self.datasource_mgr.add_datasource(req) # self.datasource_mgr.delete_datasource(result['id']) # self.assertRaises(datasource_manager.DatasourceNotFound, # self.datasource_mgr.get_datasource, # result['id']) # engine = self.cage.service_object('engine') # self.assertRaises(exception.PolicyRuntimeException, # engine.assert_policy_exists, req['name']) # # TODO(thinrichs): test that we've actually removed # # the row from the DB def test_delete_datasource_error(self): req = self._get_datasource_request() req['driver'] = 'fake_datasource' req['config'] = {'auth_url': 'foo', 'username': 'armax', 'password': 'password', 'tenant_name': 'armax'} # let driver generate this for us. del req['id'] result = self.datasource_mgr.add_datasource(req) engine = self.dseNode.service_object('engine') engine.create_policy('alice') engine.insert('p(x) :- %s:q(x)' % req['name'], 'alice') self.assertRaises(exception.DanglingReference, self.datasource_mgr.delete_datasource, result['id']) def test_delete_invalid_datasource(self): self.assertRaises(exception.DatasourceNotFound, self.datasource_mgr.delete_datasource, "does_not_exist") def test_get_driver_schema(self): schema = self.datasource_mgr.get_driver_schema( 'fake_datasource') self.assertEqual( schema, fake_datasource.FakeDataSource.get_schema()) def test_get_datasouce_schema_driver_not_found(self): self.assertRaises(exception.DatasourceNotFound, self.datasource_mgr.get_datasource_schema, "does_not_exist") def test_duplicate_driver_name_raises(self): # Load the driver twice cfg.CONF.set_override( 'drivers', ['congress.tests.fake_datasource.FakeDataSource', 'congress.tests.fake_datasource.FakeDataSource']) self.datasource_mgr = datasource_manager.DataSourceManager self.assertRaises(exception.BadConfig, self.datasource_mgr.validate_configured_drivers) def test_datasource_spawn_datasource_poll(self): req = self._get_datasource_request() req['driver'] = 'fake_datasource' req['config'] = {'auth_url': 'foo', 'username': 'armax', 'password': 'password', 'tenant_name': 'armax'} # let driver generate this for us. del req['id'] result = self.datasource_mgr.add_datasource(req) self.datasource_mgr.request_refresh(result['id']) # TODO(thinrichs): test that the driver actually polls def test_datasource_spawn_datasource_poll_not_found(self): self.assertRaises(exception.DatasourceNotFound, self.datasource_mgr.request_refresh, "does_not_exist")

commit_message:
Remove code

ContainerController and BaseObjectController are Controller subclass（
/swift/proxy/controllers/base, Controller has "GET/HEAD"，so remove
"GET/HEAD" in the ContainerController and BaseObjectController.

Change-Id: I791031fdc01369acc115521b61e95c40ecd6a3ff

commit_message:
nodejs-install macro can install different versions of node

This patch modifies the nodejs-install macro to install based on the
{version} parameter. All current uses of nodejs-install have been set to use
version '4'.

Change-Id: I73a0c5b801137d8700b16acb8375eaabfb668d5f

deleted_lines: sudo apt-get install -y nodejs nodejs-legacy npm

commit_message:
Renamed npm-install macro to nodejs-install

This patch renames the npm-install macro to nodejs-install. This
is done to be more descriptive of what the macro actually does,
as well as to reduce confusion between this macro and the
`npm install` command.

Change-Id: Ieda074b9b83da777c378aefc9ab732c5d288a9ee

commit_message:
Renamed *-npm-* jobs to *-nodejs4-npm-* jobs

In order to provide a migration path for projects to move from node4
to node6 and later, this patch renames all npm-based jobs to explicitly
describe which version of node they're running on. The npm-upload builder
was not changed, as this one executes with --no-scripts and therefore
should never depend on the running version of node. Also, it runs on the
release slave, so we cannot dynamically change the nodejs version.

Change-Id: I7eb9cddd689646b8eb8eeee69f0fd5c82d827754

commit_message:
Increase ovs-vswitchd logging for debugging

To find the cause of duplicated ofports, this patch
increases the vswitchd logging in devstack.

Related-Bug: #1599329
Change-Id: I6aa695520d0145376bdd3b78ac2689ba3d58d227
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/31/344731/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if [[ "$Q_AGENT" == "openvswitch" ]]; then # extra debugging to find root cause of bug/1599329 for subsystem in netdev netdev_linux netdev_vport poll_loop netlink netlink_notifier; do sudo ovs-appctl vlog/set $subsystem:file:dbg; done fi

commit_message:
Add build-essential to required packages for development

I ran into gcc not being available recently on a fresh Ubuntu image.
Adding it allowed tox to run fine and install ironic's dependencies. Add
it to the dev quickstart to make sure nobody else gets tripped up.

Change-Id: Ibd6e3bc4772af382c8df92d54050af4934e49ab4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/64/345064/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add class to use certmonger's local CA

This class extracts the certificate and adds it to the trusted certs.

bp tls-via-certmonger

Change-Id: I6dc1e0469cd7dbbb51659c8f29975d25b2941ec3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-tripleo refs/changes/51/344851/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2016 Red Hat, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. # # == Class: tripleo::certmonger::ca::local # # Does the necessary action to extract and trust certmonger's local CA. # class tripleo::certmonger::ca::local { $local_ca_pkcs12 = '/var/lib/certmonger/local/creds' $local_ca_pem = '/etc/pki/ca-trust/source/anchors/cm-local-ca.pem' $extract_cmd = "openssl pkcs12 -in ${local_ca_pkcs12} -out ${local_ca_pem} -nokeys -nodes -passin pass:''" $trust_ca_cmd = 'update-ca-trust extract' exec { 'extract-and-trust-ca': command => "${extract_cmd} && ${trust_ca_cmd}", path => '/usr/bin', creates => $local_ca_pem, require => Package['certmonger'], } }

commit_message:
Use bundletester for amulet test execution

Switch to using bundletester for execution of functional tests,
leveraging tox to build out test virtualenvs.

Rename amulet tests inline with gate-* and dev-* naming standards.

Update README to refer to functional testing section of the charm
guide.

Add basic multi-unit test for Xenial.

Change-Id: I06a976d9fc6418f04f46f3c3cca83d2fb47f3ee4

commit_message:
Renamed javascript-jobs to nodejs4-jobs

In order to provide a migration path for projects to move from node4
to node6 and later, this patch begins the process of following the
python{version} job pattern by renaming all 'javascript-jobs' to
explicitly describing the engine version that's used.

Change-Id: Id71b4d3f35f29317269ab10a113a497da3a29fb0

commit_message:
Temprorary disable test for cinder notification dirver

It's required to disable this test to keep our jobs green
for OpenStack puppet modules. Issue was found in
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/334845/.
Uncomment this test if we update tag for puppet-cinder module.

Change-Id: I15f8a5a597ba6521b3c6953fdafe1e1716f06e13
Closes-bug: #1568796

deleted_lines: it 'should contain notification_driver option' do if ceilometer_hash['enabled'] should contain_cinder_config('DEFAULT/notification_driver').with(:value => ceilometer_hash['notification_driver']) else should_not contain_cinder_config('DEFAULT/notification_driver') end end

subject: Enable higher performance I/O through
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-12 08:26:57.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_neutron/commit/95946b4c9e7231bce4575422b06cc4f804af2f54', 'message': 'Enable higher performance I/O through

Enable higher performance I/O through using conntrack
and remove the need to use hybrid vif plugging which slows
performance dramatically.

Change-Id: I0801b0d6925a0d3c0ae9b14d38310d5906355b98
Partially-Implements: blueprint powervm-virt-driver
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-07-13 13:00:22.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_neutron/commit/45f1afc37d558a5978ad4ff030694a482bbae8d2', 'message': "Enable higher performance I/O through

In Ubuntu 16.04 the updated kernel that is shipped has conntrack support.
The inclusion of conntrack led to a new firewall driver that removed the
need for hybrid vif plugging. Hybrid vif plugging allowed security groups
to operate properly, but led to significant performance degradation's
when paired with OVS.

Since the inclusion of OVS for the PowerVM driver occurred during the
OpenStack Newton release, it aligned well with the Ubuntu 16.04 release.
As such, the PowerVM driver team did not enable hybrid vif plugging, but
instead focused on standard plugging.

This change set allows an option to turn off the hybrid vif plugging
(for all architectures), but will automatically detect it for PowerVM
and turn it off.  This will enable deployments on newer operating systems
to have higher network I/O performance.

Change-Id: I0801b0d6925a0d3c0ae9b14d38310d5906355b98
Partially-Implements: blueprint powervm-virt-driver
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2016-07-13 13:40:43.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_neutron/commit/370d841445cbb326c3e9979830366e82f3ae156f', 'message': "Enable higher performance I/O through

commit_message:
Enable higher performance I/O through

In Ubuntu 16.04 the updated kernel that is shipped has conntrack support.
The inclusion of conntrack led to a new firewall driver that removed the
need for hybrid vif plugging. Hybrid vif plugging allowed security groups
to operate properly, but led to significant performance degradation's
when paired with OVS.

Since the inclusion of OVS for the PowerVM driver occurred during the
OpenStack Newton release, it aligned well with the Ubuntu 16.04 release.
As such, the PowerVM driver team did not enable hybrid vif plugging, but
instead focused on standard plugging.

This change set allows an option to turn off the hybrid vif plugging
(for all architectures), but will automatically detect it for PowerVM
and turn it off.  This will enable deployments on newer operating systems
to have higher network I/O performance.

Change-Id: I0801b0d6925a0d3c0ae9b14d38310d5906355b98
Partially-Implements: blueprint powervm-virt-driver

commit_message:
Remove unnecessary overrides of service variables

The cinder service user, project, region, and password are the same
regardless of the API endpoint version.

Use the existing cinder namespaced variables instead of overriding and
providing a generic 'service_' variable for use with the service setup
tasks.

This also fixes a recursive loop issue seen when deploying the
integrated release with Ansible 2.1: http://tinyurl.com/hhuljtu

Partial-Bug: 1603703
Change-Id: I469dcabb03c792abbad7f65a17bfa5f7146dcfa7
(cherry picked from commit 95276fbd94f342ad2385a2fedda86d097a25676e)

commit_message:
Fix improperly rendered Update Security Service modal form

Update Security Service form validation works for only one time.
On the second try whatever values are used, a correct ones or not,
the form closes with "There was an error submitting the form.
Please try again." message. It appears that form_invalid method
returns broken submit url. This patch moves rendering to get_initial
method to get a proper submit url for valid and invalid forms.

Change-Id: I6047adaf1a0864d93272940f8d15468b1ec39426
Closes-Bug: #1585247
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila-ui refs/changes/26/342226/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.submit_url = reverse(self.submit_url, kwargs=self.kwargs)

commit_message:
Only build venvs for services which are deployed

The current repo build process builds venvs for all OpenStack services,
regardless of whether they're actually going to be used.

To reduce the repo build time, this patch will only build venvs for
OpenStack services where there is one or more members in the service
inventory group.

Change-Id: I01e6cdaa7a1a4aa07d2118c0badfea25b85b3249
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-repo_build refs/changes/10/345310/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: repo_build_release_tag: "{{ openstack_release }}"

commit_message:
Fix improperly rendered Edit Share modal form

Edit Share form validation works for only one time. On the second try
whatever values are used, a correct ones or not, the form closes with
"There was an error submitting the form. Please try again." message.
It appears that form_invalid method returns broken submit url.
This patch moves rendering to get_initial method to get a proper
submit url for valid and invalid forms.

Change-Id: I85a18da3a72cb8d964e0372eb5ede1ae9c94bb59
Closes-Bug: #1585252

commit_message:
lb-agent: ensure tap mtu is the same as physical device

On compute-nodes, Nova creates the bridge with the tap before
the physical is in the bridge. This causes the tap to have the
default 1500 MTU which may be different to what is on the physical.
With this patch the linuxbridge agent ensures that the MTU on the
tap device is the same as what is on the physical device.

Change-Id: Id1a4f662ec33ca0333c15eb210366bc850d0d54c
Closes-Bug: 1443607
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/58/174558/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: else: phy_dev_name = self.ensure_physical_in_bridge(network_id, network_type, physical_network, segmentation_id) if not phy_dev_name: return False self.ensure_tap_mtu(tap_device_name, phy_dev_name) def ensure_tap_mtu(self, tap_dev_name, phy_dev_name): """Ensure the MTU on the tap is the same as the physical device.""" phy_dev_mtu = ip_lib.IPDevice(phy_dev_name).link.mtu ip_lib.IPDevice(tap_dev_name).link.set_mtu(phy_dev_mtu)
deleted_lines: elif not self.ensure_physical_in_bridge(network_id, network_type, physical_network, segmentation_id): return False

commit_message:
Remove unnecessary packages

Remove devel packages and other build dependencies from the container as
soon as all required dependencies have been built/installed. This will
save us some space.

Change-Id: I28327eedb51d0c3fdbf8baa7a17d4356c2af5773
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common refs/changes/89/344789/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Also note gcc, python-devel, and libyaml-devel are required for # docker-compose. It would be nice to package that or use somethinge else. # Working on getting this into centos:7 # https://admin.fedoraproject.org/pkgdb/package/rpms/docker-compose/ yum install -y \ gcc \ libyaml-devel \ python-devel \ python-pip \ docker # NOTE(flaper87): We have to use `rpm --nodeps` because some packages that we # depend on happen to depend on python-devel, which we don't need for this # container. rpm -e --nodeps python-devel # NOTE(flaper87): Remove unnecessary packages yum remove gcc "*-devel" yum autoremove -y yum clean all

commit_message:
Remove unnecessary overrides of service variables

Use the existing aodh namespaced variables instead of overriding and
providing a generic 'service_' variable for use with the service setup
tasks. The existing aodh_service_setup.yml file can be directly replaced
by aodh_service_add.yml.

Partial-Bug: 1603703
Change-Id: Ic5fa09d7fd886c4def544c87fa87002c303a4da4
(cherry picked from commit d95c404c6f530df77963900c739863e78bf4b8c6)

commit_message:
Predictable Network Interface Names

Add udev rule 80-net-name-slot.rules in filesystem and copy it in
initramfs.

Change-Id: I117ce683275bfa09877040d8a8b4fd02dc002f08
Closes-Bug: #1597695

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-21 02:01:13.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/04042d3494b05f3f84765e32daccc29e1241a728', 'message': 'Updated ansible.cfg and ssh options for Ansible 2

The Ansible configuration and ssh options have not been updated
since before we moved to Ansible "2.1.x". This change updates
our options to ensure we're using performant SSH options.

Additionally the ansible.cfg change will also ensure that our
timeout option is sensible and that the transport is "ssh".
Without setting the transport to "ssh" ansible will default to
"smart" which can flip flop between "ssh" and "paraminko" causing
serious performance problems.

commit_message:
Updated ansible.cfg and ssh options for Ansible 2

The Ansible configuration and ssh options have not been updated
since before we moved to Ansible "2.1.x". This change updates
our options to ensure we're using performant SSH options.

Additionally the ansible.cfg change will also ensure that our
timeout option is sensible and that the transport is "ssh".
Without setting the transport to "ssh" ansible will default to
"smart" which can flip flop between "ssh" and "paraminko" causing
serious performance problems.

Change-Id: I150508aec7fa4a6c55fe78f437862caa8fbc1d6d
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/24/345124/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ansible_ssh_extra_args: > -o UserKnownHostsFile=/dev/null -o ServerAliveInterval=64 -o ServerAliveCountMax=1024 -o Compression=no -o TCPKeepAlive=yes -o VerifyHostKeyDNS=no -o ForwardX11=no -o ForwardAgent=yes -T

commit_message:
Remove debconf from nova-compute-node install

As per the Keystone install, this removes the parts which
are referencing Debconf setup, and remove lots of conditionals.

Note that intentionally, the part that activates use_neutron = true
and firewall_driver is also removed from the Debian isntall guide,
as this is already the default in the Debian package.

Change-Id: Ia0b2c4875052bf08045d28eb508f7e76a3a484d8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/14/344814/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: * In the ``[DEFAULT]`` and [oslo_messaging_rabbit] sections, configure ``RabbitMQ`` message queue access: .. code-block:: ini [DEFAULT] ... rpc_backend = rabbit [oslo_messaging_rabbit] ... rabbit_host = controller rabbit_userid = openstack rabbit_password = RABBIT_PASS Replace ``RABBIT_PASS`` with the password you chose for the ``openstack`` account in ``RabbitMQ``. * In the ``[DEFAULT]`` and ``[keystone_authtoken]`` sections, configure Identity service access: .. code-block:: ini [DEFAULT] ... auth_strategy = keystone [keystone_authtoken] ... auth_uri = http://controller:5000 auth_url = http://controller:35357 memcached_servers = controller:11211 auth_type = password project_domain_name = default user_domain_name = default project_name = service username = nova password = NOVA_PASS Replace ``NOVA_PASS`` with the password you chose for the ``nova`` user in the Identity service. .. note:: Comment out or remove any other options in the ``[keystone_authtoken]`` section. * In the ``[DEFAULT]`` section, enable support for the Networking service: .. code-block:: ini [DEFAULT] ... use_neutron = True firewall_driver = nova.virt.firewall.NoopFirewallDriver .. note:: By default, Compute uses an internal firewall service. Since Networking includes a firewall service, you must disable the Compute firewall service by using the ``nova.virt.firewall.NoopFirewallDriver`` firewall driver.
deleted_lines: .. only:: obs or rdo or ubuntu * In the ``[DEFAULT]`` and [oslo_messaging_rabbit] sections, configure ``RabbitMQ`` message queue access: .. code-block:: ini [DEFAULT] ... rpc_backend = rabbit [oslo_messaging_rabbit] ... rabbit_host = controller rabbit_userid = openstack rabbit_password = RABBIT_PASS Replace ``RABBIT_PASS`` with the password you chose for the ``openstack`` account in ``RabbitMQ``. * In the ``[DEFAULT]`` and ``[keystone_authtoken]`` sections, configure Identity service access: .. code-block:: ini [DEFAULT] ... auth_strategy = keystone [keystone_authtoken] ... auth_uri = http://controller:5000 auth_url = http://controller:35357 memcached_servers = controller:11211 auth_type = password project_domain_name = default user_domain_name = default project_name = service username = nova password = NOVA_PASS Replace ``NOVA_PASS`` with the password you chose for the ``nova`` user in the Identity service. .. note:: Comment out or remove any other options in the ``[keystone_authtoken]`` section. * In the ``[DEFAULT]`` section, enable support for the Networking service: .. code-block:: ini [DEFAULT] ... use_neutron = True firewall_driver = nova.virt.firewall.NoopFirewallDriver .. note:: By default, Compute uses an internal firewall service. Since Networking includes a firewall service, you must disable the Compute firewall service by using the ``nova.virt.firewall.NoopFirewallDriver`` firewall driver.

revisions:

The dict.keys()[0] will raise a TypeError in PY3,

Closes-Bug: #1583419

commit_message:
Fix dict.keys() PY3 compatible

The dict.keys()[0] will raise a TypeError in PY3,
as dict.keys() doesn't return a list any more in PY3
but a view of list.

Change-Id: If15a153c9db9b654e761f8ad50d5d66a427efa4e
Closes-Bug: #1583419
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/watcher refs/changes/46/341946/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
